title: Independence & Togetherness
description: Learn about your balance of closeness and personal space.

questions.text: How much independence do I need in our relationship?
choices: A lot - I need significant personal space
Moderate - balance of together and apart time
Minimal - I prefer to share most activities
It varies based on circumstances

therapeutic.rationale: Independence needs reflect the balance between autonomy and connection. High-independence seekers may have avoidant attachment or healthy differentiation; moderate-seekers have flexible balance; low-independence seekers may have anxious attachment or genuine togetherness preference; variable-needers adapt to context.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different independence needs create the most common relationship struggle. The high-independence person may feel suffocated by the togetherness-seeker; the togetherness-seeker may feel abandoned. Neither is wrong—negotiate rather than judge.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared independence needs make balance easier. You'll want similar amounts of space and togetherness.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How much independence do you need? Is your current relationship providing this? What happens when you don't get enough—or get too much?

questions.text: How do I feel when you need space or alone time?
choices: Completely fine and supportive
Okay if you communicate about it
A bit insecure but I manage it
Worried that something's wrong

therapeutic.rationale: Response to partner's space-taking reveals attachment activation. Fine-and-supportive suggests secure attachment; communication-dependent suggests need for reassurance; managed-insecurity shows aware anxiety; worried-response shows activated anxious attachment. How you respond to your partner's space-taking affects whether they feel safe taking it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different responses to space-taking affect relationship dynamics. If your partner feels worried when you need space, they need reassurance that space isn't rejection.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared responses to space-taking suggest similar attachment orientations. You understand each other's relationship with alone time.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when your partner needs alone time? What thoughts arise? Does your response help them feel safe taking space?

questions.text: What's my ideal level of togetherness in our daily life?
choices: Constant connection and sharing
Regular check-ins throughout the day
Quality time morning and evening
Meaningful connection a few times a week

therapeutic.rationale: Togetherness ideals reflect connection needs. Constant-connectors have high attachment needs; regular check-inners balance connection throughout day; morning-evening connectors have transition rituals; weekly-connectors have lower frequency needs. Mismatched ideals create daily friction.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different togetherness ideals require compromise. The constant-connector may feel neglected by the weekly-connector; the weekly-connector may feel overwhelmed by constant demand. Find a rhythm that works for both.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared togetherness ideals make daily life flow. You'll naturally want similar amounts of connection.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's your ideal amount of daily togetherness? Is your relationship providing this? What would your ideal day look like?

questions.text: How do I balance my individual identity with being a couple?
choices: I maintain strong individual interests
I blend our lives while keeping some independence
I prioritize our couple identity
I sometimes lose myself in relationships

therapeutic.rationale: Identity balance in relationships reflects differentiation. Strong-individual-interest maintainers preserve selfhood; blenders find balance; couple-identity prioritizers merge more fully; self-losers may have enmeshment patterns. Healthy relationships maintain two distinct selves who choose to be together.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different identity balances may create tension. The strong-individual may feel the couple-prioritizer wants too much merger; the couple-prioritizer may feel the strong-individual is distant. Both positions are valid.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared identity balance means you approach 'we' vs 'I' similarly. You're aligned on how much to merge versus stay separate.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How well do you maintain your individual identity in your relationship? Do you lose yourself, or stay too separate? What would ideal balance look like?

questions.text: What helps me feel secure when we're physically apart?
choices: Frequent texts or calls
Knowing when we'll see each other next
Trust in our connection
Having my own activities to focus on

therapeutic.rationale: Apart-security strategies reveal attachment coping. Frequent contact maintains felt connection; knowing-when provides certainty; trust allows secure confidence; own-activities shift focus. Understanding what helps your partner feel secure during separation helps you provide it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different apart-security needs mean different things help each of you. The frequent-texter may feel abandoned by the trust-based partner; the own-activities person may feel smothered by constant contact.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared apart-security strategies mean you'll naturally help each other feel connected during separation.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps you feel secure when your partner isn't around? Do you need contact, or can you trust the connection? What would help you feel more secure apart?
